an5.99:4.1: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his lair,
an5.99:4.3: looks all around the four directions,
an5.99:4.4: and roars his lion’s roar three times.
an5.99:4.5: Then he sets out on the hunt.
an5.99:4.6: If he strikes an elephant, he does it carefully, not carelessly.
an5.99:4.10: or any smaller creatures—even a hare or a cat—he does it carefully, not carelessly.
an5.99:4.12: Thinking: ‘May I not lose my way.’
an5.99:5.1: ‘Lion’ is a term for the Realized One, the Perfect One, the fully awakened Buddha.
an5.99:5.2: When the Realized One teaches Dharma to an assembly, this is his lion’s roar.
an5.99:5.3: When the Realized One teaches the monks …
an5.99:5.7: or ordinary people—even food-carriers and hunters—he teaches them carefully, not carelessly.
an5.99:5.9: Because the Realized One has respect and reverence for the Dharma.”
